title: Sources
text:
The dataset was sourced from Kaggle. The data used was the primary cohort from Norway, consisting of 110,204 patient admissions with sepsis.

https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/joebeachcapital/sepsis-survival-minimal-clinical-records

Information on Sepsis in this website was sourced from Cleveland Clinic.

https://my.clevelandclinic.org/health/diseases/12361-sepsis

title: Episode number and Survivale Rate Model
text:
# Load in all the libraries that may be used in model and graph creation.
library(tidyverse)
library(gtsummary)
library(tidybayes)
library(brms)
library(broom.mixed)

# Read in the data
sepsis_data <- read.csv("data/s41598-020-73558-3_sepsis_survival_primary_cohort.csv")


# Mutate and edit the data
#| label: edit data
sepsis_data <- sepsis_data |>
  mutate(
    outcome = hospital_outcome_1alive_0dead)


# Make the model with episode number as the covariate to outcome.
fit_episode <- brm(
  formula = outcome ~ episode_number,
  family = bernoulli(),
  data = sepsis_data,
  silent = 2, 
  refresh = 0)


tbl_regression(fit_episode)

Warning in tidy.brmsfit(x, ..., effects = "fixed"): some parameter names
contain underscores: term naming may be unreliable!













Characteristic
Beta
95% CI
1




episode_number
-0.03
-0.06, 0.00



1
CI = Credible Interval









# Make new object for predictions
newobs <- tibble(
  episode_number = c( 1, 2, 3, 4, 5))


# Define a color palette with shades of blue
colors <- c(
  "1" = "#1f77b4", # blue
  "2" = "#3399cc", # lighter blue
  "3" = "#66b2ff", # even lighter blue
  "4" = "#99ccff", # light blue
  "5" = "#cce5ff"  # very light blue
)

# Plot the predictions
fit_episode |> 
  # Generate predictions
  add_epred_draws(newdata = newobs) |>
  # Make episode-number a factor, flip order of bottom to top
  ggplot(aes(x = .epred, y = fct_rev(factor(episode_number)), fill = factor(episode_number))) + 
  stat_slab() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = colors) +
  # Add labels
  labs(
    title = "Predicted Probability of Surviving by Episode Number",
    subtitle = "Increased episodes result in a lower survival probability",
    x = "Predicted Probability of Surviving",
    y = "Episode Number",
    fill = "Episode Number"
  ) +
  # Change x-axis to percent format
  scale_x_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1)) +
  # Change background to be cleaner
  theme_minimal()








\[ \text{logit}(\pi_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{episode\_number}_i \]

title: Ages
text:
To see the effect of age we use the following equation…
\[\text{logit}(\pi_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{age}_i \]
From this we see that for every additional year of age, survival rate decreases.

title: Episode Numbers
text:
To see the individual effects of the variables on survival rate, we modeled the variable of the number of episodes using the following equation…
\[ \text{logit}(\pi_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{episode\_number}_i \]
We receive the resulting effect…

title: Genders
text:
We used the following equation to model the effects of gender on the survival rate…
\[\text{logit}(\pi_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{gender}_{i,\text{Male}}\]
From the results we see that females have a slightly higher chance of survival than males.

title: Home
text:
By using a data set from Norway on 110,204 patient admissions of people with Sepsis from 2011 to 2012, we wanted to understand the probability of survival based upon the factors of numbers of previous episodes of Sepsis and gender. The data was sourced from Kaggle on containing de-identified data on hospitalized patients. It includes the variables of sex, age, episode number and survival outcome.Though healthcare has dramatically changed over the years, we believe for these predictions to hold true. We used a logistic regression model with the variables of age (numeric variable), sex (categorical variable) and episode number (numeric) set to the outcome of the probability of survival for the i-th individual. From modeling the variables as a logistic function to the outcome, we discovered that being female can increases the odds of survival by 18%, higher age decreases the probability of survival by 4%, while higher episode numbers have slightly lower chance of survival of about 3%, though it may be as much as 5% or as low as 0%.

Sepsis Survival Rate:
(Episode number refers to the number of times a patient has had Sepsis)











Overview of Sepsis:
Sepsis is a dangerous condition that can occur to anyone. It happens when the body’s immune system responds improperly to infection and damages healthy tissue. This can lead to organ failure, widespread inflammation and possibly death. Sepsis itself is not a disease, but rather caused by other infectious diseases.
Important symptoms to lookout for are…
-  Rashes

-  Change in heart rate

-  Change in body temperature

-  Fatigue

-  Disorientation

-  Discomfort

-  Clammy or sweaty skin

-  Shivers or chills

title: Main model
text:
To model the effects of different variables on the probability of survival, we used the following equation…
\[
\text{logit}(\pi_i) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{age}_i + \beta_2 \cdot \text{sex}_{i,\text{Male}} + \beta_3 \cdot \text{episode\_number}_i
\]
We recieve the following results indicating a positive effect on the probability of survival if one is female, while there is a decrease in the probability if one is of older age or has more episode numbers…













Characteristic
Beta
95% CI
1




age
-0.04
-0.05, -0.04


sex






    Male
—
—


    Female
0.18
0.13, 0.23


episode_number
-0.03
-0.06, 0.00



1
CI = Credible Interval








To visually interpret the survival probability, the model is graphed by taking draws and using the average age of patients.









From this we see that females of younger age with less episode numbers have the highest likelihood of survival while males of older age with more episode numbers would have the lowest likelihood of survival.
